Independent Auditors’ Report
To the Plans Administration Committee of Citigroup Inc.
The Citigroup Pension Plan:
Opinion
We have audited the financial statements of The Citigroup Pension Plan (the Plan), an employee benefit plan
subject to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA), which comprise the statements of
net assets available for benefits as of December 31, 2024 and 2023, and the related statements of changes in
net assets available for benefits for the years then ended, and the related notes to the financial statements.
In our opinion, the accompanying financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the net assets
available for benefits of the Plan as of December 31, 2024 and 2023, and the changes in its net assets
available for benefits for the years then ended, in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting
principles.
Basis for Opinion
We conducted our audits in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United States of
America (GAAS). Our responsibilities under those standards are further described in the Auditors’
Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements section of our report. We are required to be
independent of the Plan and to meet our other ethical responsibilities, in accordance with the relevant ethical
requirements relating to our audits. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and
appropriate to provide a basis for our audit opinion.
Responsibilities of Management for the Financial Statements
Management is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the financial statements in accordance
with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles, and for the design, implementation, and maintenance of
internal control relevant to the preparation and fair presentation of financial statements that are free from
material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error.
In preparing the financial statements, management is required to evaluate whether there are conditions or
events, considered in the aggregate, that raise substantial doubt about the Plan’s ability to continue as a going
concern for one year after the date that the financial statements are available to be issued.
Management is also responsible for maintaining a current plan instrument, including all plan amendments,
administering the Plan, and determining that the Plan's transactions that are presented and disclosed in the
financial statements are in conformity with the Plan's provisions, including maintaining sufficient records with
respect to each of the participants, to determine the benefits due or which may become due to such
participants.
Auditors’ Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements
Our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements as a whole are free
from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditors’ report that includes our
opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance but is not absolute assurance and therefore is not
a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with GAAS will always detect a material misstatement when
it exists. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting
from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of
internal control. Misstatements are considered material if there is a substantial likelihood that, individually or in
KPMG LLP, a Delaware limited liability partnership and a member firm of
the KPMG global organization of independent member firms affiliated with
K PMG International Limited, a private English company limited by guarantee.

the aggregate, they would influence the judgment made by a reasonable user based on the financial
statements.
In performing an audit in accordance with GAAS, we:
● Exercise professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism throughout the audit.
● Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the financial statements, whether due to fraud
or error, and design and perform audit procedures responsive to those risks. Such procedures include
examining, on a test basis, evidence regarding the amounts and disclosures in the financial
statements.
● Obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit procedures that
are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the
effectiveness of the Plan’s internal control. Accordingly, no such opinion is expressed.
● Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of significant
accounting estimates made by management, as well as evaluate the overall presentation of the
financial statements.
● Conclude whether, in our judgment, there are conditions or events, considered in the aggregate, that
raise substantial doubt about the Plan’s ability to continue as a going concern for a reasonable period
of time.
We are required to communicate with those charged with governance regarding, among other matters, the
planned scope and timing of the audit, significant audit findings, and certain internal control related matters that
we identified during the audit.
Supplemental Schedules Required by ERISA
Our audits were conducted for the purpose of forming an opinion on the financial statements as a whole. The
supplemental schedules of Schedule H, line 4i - Schedule of Assets (Held at End of Year) as of December 31,
2024, Schedule H, line 4i - Schedule of Assets (Acquired and Disposed of Within Year) for the year ended
December 31, 2024, Schedule H, line 4j - Schedule of Reportable Transactions for the year ended
December 31, 2024, and Schedule G, Part I - Schedule of Fixed Income Obligations in Default or Classified as
Uncollectible as of December 31, 2024 are presented for purposes of additional analysis and are not a required
part of the financial statements but are supplementary information required by the Department of Labor's Rules
and Regulations for Reporting and Disclosure under ERISA. Such information is the responsibility of
management and was derived from and relates directly to the underlying accounting and other records used to
prepare the financial statements. The information has been subjected to the auditing procedures applied in the
audits of the financial statements and certain additional procedures, including comparing and reconciling such
information directly to the underlying accounting and other records used to prepare the financial statements or
to the financial statements themselves, and other additional procedures in accordance with GAAS.
In forming our opinion on the supplemental schedules, we evaluated whether the supplemental schedules,
including their form and content, are presented in conformity with the Department of Labor's Rules and
Regulations for Reporting and Disclosure under ERISA.
In our opinion, the information in the accompanying schedules is fairly stated, in all material respects, in relation
to the financial statements as a whole, and the form and content are presented in conformity with the
Department of Labor's Rules and Regulations for Reporting and Disclosure under ERISA.

Notes to Financial Statements
December 31, 2024 and 2023
(1) Plan Description
The following brief description of The Citigroup Pension Plan (the Plan) is provided for general information
purposes only. Participants should refer to the Plan document for a complete description of the Plan’s
provisions.
(a) General
The Plan is a defined benefit pension plan sponsored by Citigroup Inc. and participating affiliates
(collectively, the Plan Sponsor or the Company). The Plan was designed to provide benefits to all
eligible employees of the Company upon reaching retirement age or after termination. Effective
January 1, 2008, the Plan was frozen for most employees. The Plan is subject to the provisions of the
Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, as amended (ERISA).
The Company offers postretirement healthcare benefits to certain eligible U.S. retired employees, their
spouses and dependents. In accordance with Section 401(h) of the Internal Revenue Code (IRC), a
separate account was established (Retiree Medical Account (RMA) – note 11), consisting of Company
contributions made with the intention of providing future healthcare benefits to eligible retired
employees under the Citigroup Retiree Medical Benefit Plan (the Retiree Medical Plan). The assets of
the RMA are commingled with the Plan assets and are held in a trust (the Trust) for investment
purposes and are included in investments, at fair value on the statements of net assets available for
benefits.
Bank of New York Mellon is the trustee of the assets of the Trust established in connection with the
Plan. The Plan engages registered investment advisors (investment managers) to invest the Plan’s
assets on its behalf.
(b) Benefits
Plan benefits are determined based on age, completed years of service and eligible compensation of
participants. Participants are 100% vested in their benefits after three years of vesting service, upon
reaching age 55 with one year of service, upon terminating employment by reason of disability, or if
the participant dies while actively employed by the Company.
The Plan consists of a cash balance formula, granting compensation-based benefit credits and interest
credits to participants, as well as grandfathered pension formulas and ongoing traditional annuity
benefit accruals to certain long-service employees of legacy pension plans. The Plan was closed to
new participants effective January 1, 2008. In addition, no additional compensation-based
contributions were credited to the cash balance portion of the Plan for existing Plan participants after
that date although interest credits will continue to accrue. Employees covered under grandfathered
pension formulas generally continued to accrue benefits under their respective grandfathered formula.
(c) Expenses
Administrative and investment management expenses of the Plan are generally paid by the Plan to the
extent allowed in accordance with the Plan document. The Plan Sponsor may elect to pay for certain
expenses.

Certain expenses related to brokerage commissions, trading fees, investment management fees,
incentive allocations and other expenses resulting from purchases and sales of investments within the

(2) Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
(a) Basis of Accounting
The accompanying financial statements have been prepared under the accrual basis of accounting.
(b) Use of Estimates
The preparation of the financial statements in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting
principles (GAAP) requires the Plan’s management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the
reported amounts of assets and liabilities, changes therein, and disclosure of contingent assets and
liabilities and the actuarial present value of accumulated plan benefits, and changes therein, at the date
the financial statements are prepared. Actual results could differ from those estimates and assumptions.
Significant estimates inherent in the preparation of the financial statements include the fair value of
investments.
(c) Investments Valuation and Income Recognition
The Plan’s investments are stated at fair value.
The Plan’s investments include separately managed accounts held in the Trust, as well as an immediate
participation guarantee contract with MetLife Insurance Company of Connecticut and group annuity
contracts maintained by John Hancock Life Insurance Company, which were issued in 2022.
The Plan’s investments in separately managed accounts are reported in the financial statements at the
underlying security level. The fair value of such investments is based on the year-end fair values of
those securities.
Cash equivalents and short-term investments, including money market funds, are valued at cost, which
approximates fair value.
The fair values of mutual funds and other registered investment companies and equities traded on
national securities exchanges are determined by closing prices on the last business day of the period;
securities traded in the over-the-counter (OTC) market and listed securities for which no sale was
reported on the valuation date are valued at the average of the last reported bid and ask prices; debt
securities for which published quotations are not available are valued based on yields currently
available on comparable securities of other issuers with similar credit ratings; and long-term debt
securities are valued using the latest available bid prices as quoted by dealers making a market in the
securities. Exchange-traded derivatives are valued using market observable prices.
Insurance contracts are valued based on the contract value which approximates fair value.
6 (Continued)

THE CITIGROUP PENSION PLAN
Notes to Financial Statements
December 31, 2024 and 2023
Commingled funds are valued based on NAV, which is based on the fair value of the underlying
securities that have readily determinable fair values.
OTC derivatives, which include swaps, options and forwards, are valued by using pricing models that
incorporate market inputs that are relevant and appropriate for pricing the securities. The models use
yield curves to perform standard arbitrage-free discounted cash flow and expected cash flow
calculations of prices based on the durations of the securities.
The other investments category includes primarily derivatives and a timber investment. The timber
investment is stated at estimated fair value which reflects the underlying fair value of its assets,
including timber assets appraised by independent third-party appraisal firms, and liabilities.
Limited partnerships, hedge funds and private equities for which published quotations are not available
are valued at estimated fair value as determined by the general partner or investment manager of that
investment. These investments are reported at NAV or its equivalent as a practical expedient for fair
value in accordance with the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) Accounting Standards
Codification (ASC) 820, Fair Value Measurement. The Plan’s trustee generally receives monthly
valuations for hedge funds and quarterly valuations for private equity funds. The Plan’s management
reviews monthly and quarterly investment valuations as part of the ongoing monitoring of the Plan’s
investments.
Purchases and sales of investments are recorded on a trade-date basis. Where investments in a security
have been bought at different prices, average cost is used to determine gains and losses on sales of the
investments. Securities purchased or sold near year-end may result in payments on these securities not
being made or received until after the Plan’s year-end. The amounts of such payments are recorded as
payables or receivables as of year-end in the statements of net assets available for benefits. Interest
income is recorded as earned on the accrual basis. Dividend income is recorded on the ex-dividend
date.
(d) Translation of Investments Denominated in Foreign Currencies
The cost and fair values of investments denominated in foreign currencies are translated into
U.S. dollars at each statement of net assets date using the current London interbank spot mid-market
quotation. Foreign currency gains or losses are included in net appreciation in fair value of investments.
Foreign exchange gains and losses on forward contracts are recognized based on mid-market rates
adjusted for the forward premium and are included in net appreciation in fair value of investments.
(e) Payment of Benefits
Benefit payments are recorded when paid.
The Plan purchased several group annuity contracts from various insurance carriers in order to fund
certain benefit payments. Certain contracts are allocated to individual participants and were recognized
as a deduction from net assets when purchased. The Plan pays participants their Plan benefit directly
and receives a reimbursement from the insurance carriers for the portion that is the responsibility of
the respective insurance carrier. The benefit payments to participants and reimbursements related to
these contracts are not reflected in the statements of changes in net assets available for benefits. Certain

other contracts are not fully allocated and remain assets of the Plan. The benefit payments and
reimbursements received under these unallocated contracts are reflected as benefits paid to participants

(3) Actuarial Present Value of Accumulated Plan Benefits
Accumulated plan benefits are those future periodic payments, including lump-sum distributions that are
attributable under the Plan’s provisions to the service employees have rendered.
Accumulated plan benefits include benefits expected to be paid to (a) retired or terminated employees or
their beneficiaries, (b) beneficiaries of employees who have died and (c) active employees or their
beneficiaries.
The actuarial present value of accumulated plan benefits is determined by independent actuaries and is the
amount that results from applying actuarial assumptions to adjust the accumulated plan benefits to reflect
the time value of money (through discounts for interest) and the probability of payment (by means of
decrements, such as death, disability, withdrawal, or retirement) between the valuation date and the expected
dates of payments.

(4) Contributions
The Plan is subject to the minimum funding requirements of ERISA, which are actuarially determined and
have been met for 2024 and 2023. There were no required cash contributions during 2024 and 2023.
(5) Investments
The Plan’s investment strategies are to invest in a prudent manner for the exclusive purpose of providing
benefits to participants. The investment strategies are targeted to produce a total return that, when combined
with Company contributions, if any, will maintain the Plan’s ability to meet all required benefit obligations.
Risk is controlled through diversification of asset types and investments in domestic and international
equities, fixed-income securities, other investments and cash. The assets of the Plan are diversified to limit
the impact of any individual investment. Assets are diversified across multiple asset classes, with cash and
cash equivalents, publicly traded debt securities and limited partnerships and other investments representing
the most significant asset allocations. Investments in these asset classes are further diversified across funds,
managers, strategies, vintages, sectors and geographies, depending on the specific characteristics of each
asset class.

fund combines investment capital from multiple investors and is overseen by professional investment

Long/short hedge funds are managed portfolios of investments that involve taking long positions in
investments that are expected to increase in value and short positions in investments that are expected
to decrease in value.
Event driven hedge funds are managed portfolios of investments where the manager takes a position
in a certain number of companies with special situations. This can include, but is not limited to,
mergers and distressed situations.
Global macro hedge funds are managed portfolios of investments where the manager positions the
portfolio on macroeconomic principles.
Multi strategy hedge funds employ multiple strategies to diversify risks and reduce volatility.
Fixed income hedge fund’s objective is to generate attractive risk-adjusted returns in excess of the
Bloomberg U.S. Treasury 7-10 Year Index by trading primarily in U.S. Treasuries and short-term
corporate debt securities, which may include non-investment grade securities.
Private equity investments are equity capital that are not quoted on a public exchange. Investments are
made directly into private companies or buyouts of public companies. There is a required holding
period rendering these investments illiquid. Distributions for investments in the category are received
through the liquidation of the underlying investments of the fund and therefore are not redeemable.
(b) Derivatives
Derivatives are financial instruments whose cash flows are based on a notional amount or an
underlying instrument, where there is little or no initial investment and whose terms require or permit
net settlement. Derivative instruments include swaps, options, forwards and futures.
Derivative instruments are acquired and held to add incremental value and to reduce investment risk.
Although the contract or notional amount of these instruments is not recorded on the financial
statements, these instruments are recognized as either an investment asset or a liability, depending on
the rights or obligations of the contract measured at fair value. As of December 31, 2024 and 2023,
the Plan held derivative assets of $35,717,969 and $80,974,383, respectively, which are included in
the investments at fair value as reported in the statements of net assets available for benefits and are
included in other investments, levels 1 and 2 on the fair value hierarchy table. Derivative liabilities are
included in the other investment liabilities amount in the statements of net assets available for benefits.
As of December 31, 2024 and 2023, the Plan held ($39,889,165) and ($46,895,253), respectively, of
derivative liabilities.
Derivative instruments may involve, to varying degrees, elements of credit and market risk in excess
of amounts recognized in the financial statements. The Plan minimizes the credit (or repayment) risk
in these instruments by entering into transactions with high-quality counterparties. The Plan manages
market risk by establishing and monitoring limits as to the type and degree of risk that may be
undertaken.
There were no derivative contracts accounted for as hedging instruments under FASB ASC 815,
Derivatives and Hedging, during 2024 and 2023.

(i) Forward Foreign Currency Contracts
In order to mitigate foreign currency exchange rate risks or for investment purposes, the
investment managers of the Plan may buy or sell forward foreign currency contracts.
Investments in forward foreign currency contracts obligate one party to purchase and the other
party to sell a specific currency at a set price on a future date. Forward foreign currency contracts
are valued monthly based on forward market rates, with the resulting adjustment being recorded
as unrealized gain (loss), which is included on the statements of changes in net assets available
for benefits as net appreciation (depreciation) in the fair value of investments.
15 (Continued)

THE CITIGROUP PENSION PLAN
Notes to Financial Statements
December 31, 2024 and 2023
Certain risks result from investing in foreign securities that have additional risks compared to
the usual risks inherent in domestic investments. Such risks include future political, economic
and currency exchange developments including investment restrictions and changes in foreign
laws. The investment manager and by extension, the Plan is also subject to the credit risk that
the other party will not complete the obligation of the contract.
(ii) Futures Contracts
In order to gain exposure to, or protect against, declines in security values, inclusive of foreign
currency, equity, commodity and interest rate driven changes, the investment managers of the
Plan may buy and sell futures contracts. Futures contracts generally are sold to mitigate declines
in the value of portfolio securities. The Plan may also purchase futures contracts to gain exposure
to market changes as it may be more efficient or cost-effective than actually buying securities.
Variation margin payments are equal to the daily changes in contract value and are recorded as
realized gains and losses, which are included on the statements of changes in net assets available
for benefits as part of net appreciation (depreciation) in the fair value of investments.
Risks of entering into futures contracts include the possibility that there may be an illiquid
market and that changes in the value of the contract may not correlate with changes in the value
of the underlying securities.
(iii) Options
In order to mitigate certain risks, such as interest rate risk, or to speculate on changes in the
expected direction of underlying prices, investment managers of the Plan may buy or sell
options. An option is a derivative instrument that specifies a contract between two parties for a
future transaction on an asset at a reference price. The buyer of the option gains the right, but
not the obligation, to engage in the transaction, while the seller incurs the corresponding
obligation to fulfill the transaction.
Certain risks result from investing in options. Risks of entering into options contracts include
the possibility that there may be an illiquid market and that the changes in the value of the
contract may not correlate with changes in the value of the underlying securities.
(iv) Swaps
In order to mitigate certain risks, such as interest rate risk and credit risk, or to speculate on
changes in the expected direction of underlying prices, the investment managers of the Plan may
use swaps. A swap is a financial contract between two parties, where each party pays the other
party periodic payments over the life of the contract according to some pre-specified rules based
on a certain underlying index. In most swaps, one party makes the fixed payments while the
other party delivers the floating payments according to the underlying index. Gains and losses
on swaps are included in net appreciation (depreciation) in the Plan’s statements of changes in
net assets.

Certain risks result from investing in swaps. There is price risk which arises due to the movement
of the underlying index so that the values of future payments change. This risk can be minimized
by taking offsetting positions. There is also default risk which is exposure to the risk of failure
of the counterparty.
(6) Fair Value Measurements
FASB ASC 820 provides a framework for measuring fair value, which provides a fair value hierarchy that
prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value. The hierarchy gives the highest
priority to unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities (Level 1
measurements) and the lowest priority to unobservable inputs (Level 3 measurements). The three levels of
the fair value hierarchy are described below:
• Level 1 – Quoted prices for identical instruments in active markets.
• Level 2 – Quoted prices for similar instruments in active markets; quoted prices for identical or similar
instruments in markets that are not active; and model-derived valuations in which all significant inputs
and significant value drivers are observable in active markets.
• Level 3 – Valuations derived from valuation techniques in which one or more significant inputs or
significant value drivers are unobservable.
This hierarchy requires the Plan’s management to use observable market data, when available, and to
minimize the use of unobservable inputs when determining fair value. As required by ASC 820, assets and
liabilities are classified in their entirety based on the lowest level of input that is significant to the fair value
measurement.
The methods described above may produce a fair value measurement that may not be indicative of net
realizable value or reflective of future fair values. Furthermore, while the Plan believes its valuation methods
are appropriate, the use of different methodologies or assumptions to determine the fair value of certain
financial instruments could result in a different fair value measurement at the reporting date.
FASB ASC 820 investments for which fair value is measured using the NAV per share practical expedient
are excluded from the fair value hierarchy.

(7) Risks and Uncertainties
The investment managers of the Plan invest in various investment securities. Investment securities, in
general, are exposed to various risks such as interest rate, credit and overall market volatility risk. Due to the
level of risk associated with certain investment securities, it is reasonable to expect that changes in the values
of investment securities will occur in the near term and that such changes could materially affect the amounts
reported in the statements of net assets available for benefits.
The Plan may indirectly invest in securities with contractual cash flows, such as asset-backed securities. The
value, liquidity and related income of these securities are sensitive to changes in economic conditions and
may be adversely affected by shifts in the market’s perception of the issuers and changes in interest rates.
In the normal course of business, the Plan enters into transactions in various financial instruments with
off-balance-sheet risk. These financial instruments involve varying degrees and types of risks, including
credit and market risks, which may be in excess of the amounts recognized in the statements of net assets
available for benefits of the Plan.
19 (Continued)

THE CITIGROUP PENSION PLAN
Notes to Financial Statements
December 31, 2024 and 2023
Credit risk represents the potential loss to the Plan due to possible nonperformance by obligors and
counterparties of the terms in their contracts. Market risk represents the potential loss to the Plan due to the
decrease or increase in the value of an on- or off-balance-sheet financial instrument caused primarily by
changes in interest rates or foreign exchange rates or a combination thereof.
The Plan employs the use of derivatives to mitigate interest rate exposure relative to its liabilities in order to
reduce funding level volatility.
Forward contracts and futures represent commitments to purchase or sell securities, money market
instruments or foreign currencies at a future date and at a specified price. Both credit and market risks exist
with respect to forward contracts. Market risk exists with respect to futures. These positions are carried at
current fair value and the unrealized gain or loss is included in limited partnerships and other investments
and other investment liabilities. Financial futures are marked to market and settled with the broker on a daily
basis. The Plan does not anticipate that losses, if any, as a result of credit or market risk would materially
affect the net assets available for benefits of the Plan. The Plan, to a limited extent, enters into transactions
involving other financial instruments and commitments as an integral part of the overall management of the
investment portfolio.
Plan contributions are made and the actuarial present value of accumulated plan benefits are reported, based
on certain assumptions pertaining to interest rates, inflation rates and employee demographics, all of which
are subject to change. Due to uncertainties inherent in the estimations and assumptions process, it is at least
reasonably possible that changes in these estimates and assumptions in the near term would be material to
the financial statements.
(8) Plan Termination
Although the Company has not expressed any intent to do so, it has the right to terminate the Plan in
accordance with the Plan provisions and the provisions set forth under ERISA. In the event the Plan
terminates, the net assets of the Plan will be allocated, as prescribed under ERISA and its related regulations,
generally to provide the following benefits in the order indicated:
1. Annuity benefits that former employees or their beneficiaries have been receiving for at least
three years, or that employees eligible to retire for that three-year period would have been receiving if
they had retired with benefits in the normal form of annuity under the Plan. The priority amount is
limited to the lowest benefit that was payable (or would have been payable) during those three years.
The amount is further limited to the lowest benefit that would be payable under plan provisions in
effect at any time during the five years preceding plan termination.
2. Other vested benefits insured by the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (PBGC) (a
U.S. government agency) up to the applicable limitations (discussed below).
3. All other vested benefits (that is, vested benefits not insured by the PBGC).
4. All nonvested benefits.
20 (Continued)

THE CITIGROUP PENSION PLAN
Notes to Financial Statements
December 31, 2024 and 2023
Additionally, the PBGC insures certain benefits under the Plan if the Plan so terminates. Generally, the
PBGC guarantees most vested normal retirement benefits, early retirement benefits, and certain disability
and survivor’s pensions. However, the PBGC does not guarantee all types of benefits under the Plan, and the
amount of benefit protection is subject to certain limitations. Whether all participants will receive their
benefits should the Plan terminate at some future time will depend on the sufficiency, at that time, of the
Plan’s net assets available for benefits to provide for accumulated benefit obligations and may also depend
on the financial condition of the Plan Sponsor and level of benefits guaranteed by the PBGC. There is a
statutory ceiling on the amount of an individual’s monthly benefit that the PBGC guarantees, which is
adjusted periodically and adjusted for timing and form of payment. For plan terminations occurring during
2025, the ceiling is $7,432 per month for a straight life annuity in the year a participant attains age 65.
(9) Tax Status
The Plan was amended and restated effective January 1, 2020. By notice dated February 5, 2021, the Plan
obtained a favorable determination letter from the Internal Revenue Service (IRS), in which the IRS
determined that the terms of the Plan, as amended and restated effective January 1, 2020, were in compliance
with the applicable requirements of the IRC.
Further, by notices dated September 18, 2025, the Plan obtained favorable determinations from the Puerto
Rico Department of Treasury (PR Treasury), that the terms of the Plan, as amended and restated effective
January 1, 2020, and Amendments 1 and 3 thereto were in compliance with applicable requirements under
the Puerto Rico Internal Revenue Code of 1994, as amended (PRIRC).
Although the Plan has been amended since receiving the February 5, 2021 determination letter from the IRS,
the Plan’s management and the Plan’s legal counsel believe that the Plan, as amended and restated, continues
to be qualified as exempt and continues to operate in compliance with the applicable requirements of the
IRC. The Plan administrator and its counsel are aware of no aspect of the Plan’s design or operation that
would result in the Plan’s disqualification under the applicable provisions of the IRC and the PRIRC.
Therefore, no provision for income taxes has been included in the Plan’s financial statements.
GAAP requires the Plan’s management to evaluate tax positions taken by the Plan and recognize a tax
liability (or asset) if the Plan has taken an uncertain position that more likely than not would not be sustained
upon examination by the IRS and the PR Treasury. The Plan’s management and counsel have analyzed the
tax positions taken by the Plan and have concluded that as of December 31, 2024, there are no uncertain
positions taken or expected to be taken that would require recognition of a liability (or asset) or disclosure
in the financial statements.
The Plan is subject to audits by taxing jurisdictions. An examination of the Plan by the U.S. Department of
Labor, Employee Benefits Security Administration, although not a taxing jurisdiction, is in progress. The
Plan Sponsor believes the Plan is no longer subject to tax examination for years prior to 2021.

(10) Party-in-Interest Transactions
The Plan incurs costs for services provided by the Plan’s trustee, administrator, investment managers and
others. Under ERISA, these entities are considered related parties-in-interest and are allowable under ERISA
regulations. The Plan’s payments for these services are exempt from the prohibited transaction provisions of
ERISA.
(11) Retiree Medical Account
As explained in note 1, the RMA was established to pay healthcare benefits and related administrative
expenses incurred by eligible retirees and their beneficiaries. These retirees share in the cost of their
healthcare benefits through co-payments, service-related contributions and salary-related deductibles. In
accordance with Section 401(h) of the IRC, the net assets of the RMA may not be used for, or diverted to,
any purpose other than providing health benefits for eligible retirees and their beneficiaries. Plan participants
do not contribute to the RMA.
Effective January 1, 2011, the net assets of the RMA were allocated between the Health Plan and the Retiree
Medical Plan in accordance with the creation of the Retiree Medical Plan. Net assets of the RMA are
allocated between the Health Plan and the Retiree Medical Plan based on claims paid. The related obligations
for health benefits are not included in this Plan’s accumulated benefit obligations but are reflected as
obligations of the Health Plan and the Retiree Medical Plan.
The Retiree Medical Plan was amended effective January 1, 2021 to move grandfathered Medicare-eligible
retirees to the Medicare individual marketplace. As a result, the net assets of the RMA were fully allocated
to the Retiree Medical Plan.
Net assets of the RMA were $148,607,226 and $174,781,956 as of December 31, 2024 and 2023,
respectively. The RMA accounted for 1.510% and 1.693% of the Plan’s net assets per the Form 5500 as of
December 31, 2024 and 2023, respectively.
Employer contributions to the RMA are determined annually and are at the discretion of the Company. The
Company made $0 contributions to the RMA for the years ended December 31, 2024 and 2023.
(12) Subsequent Events
The Plan’s management further evaluated subsequent events through September 30, 2025, the date on which
the financial statements were available to be issued. The Plan is not aware of any other subsequent events
that would require recognition or disclosure in the financial statements.

whether to contribute additional amounts (e.g., to reach certain funded
status thresholds, to minimize PBGC premiums, avoid ERISA 4010
filings or meet other requirements).

Actuarial Methods – Contributions
Measurement date First day of plan year
Funding target Present value of accrued benefits
The IRC 430 regulations describe the required methodology for
attributing benefits among Funding Target, current year Target
Normal Cost, and future years’ Target Normal Costs for disability
benefits, Social Security benefits, death benefits and other ancillary
benefits.
Target Normal Cost Present value of benefits expected to accrue during plan year plus
plan-related expenses expected to be paid from plan assets during
plan year
Actuarial value of assets Average of the fair market value of assets on the valuation date
and the two immediately preceding valuation dates, adjusted for
contributions, benefits, administrative expenses and expected
earnings (with such expected earnings limited as described in IRS
Notice 2009-22). The average asset value must be within 10% of
market value, including discounted contributions receivable
(discounted using the effective interest rate for the 2023 plan year.)
Benefits not valued All benefits described in the Plan Provisions section of this report
were valued. WTW has reviewed the plan provisions with Citigroup
and, based on that review, is not aware of any other significant
benefits required to be valued that were not.
Sources of Data and Other Information
Citigroup through its third-party administrators, furnished participant data and claims data as of
1/1/2024. Information on assets, contributions and plan provisions was supplied by the plan sponsor.
Data were reviewed for reasonableness and consistency, but no audit was performed. Based on
discussions with the plan sponsor, assumptions or estimates were made when data were not available,
and the data was adjusted to reflect any significant events that occurred between the date the data was
collected and the measurement date. In consultation with and approved by Citigroup, the 2024 data
action plans document the assumptions made for any missing data.
We are not aware of any errors or omissions in the data that would have a significant effect on the
results of our calculations.

Assumptions Rationale - Significant Economic Assumptions
Discount rate – Contributions The basis chosen was selected by the plan sponsor from among
choices prescribed by law, all of which are based on observed
market data over certain periods of time.
Expected return on plan We understand that the expected return on assets assumption
assets reflects the plan sponsor’s estimate of future experience for trust
asset returns, reflecting the plan‘s current asset allocation and
any expected changes during the current plan year, current
market conditions and the plan sponsor’s expectations for future
market conditions. The analysis was informed by analysis of
historical data, benchmarking data, economists’ forecasts and
recent trends for CPI, GDP growth, and real returns on the
various classes of assets held by the trust. Willis Towers
Watson’s determination that this assumption does not significantly
conflict with what would be reasonable is informed by Willis
Towers Watson’s Expected Return Estimator model and historical
active management premiums experienced by the trust.
Cash balance interest The plan credits interest to cash balance accounts using the 30-
crediting rate year Treasury rate. The plan sponsor has selected an expected
future 30-year Treasury rate of 1% less than the discount rate for
Pension Cost and the average of the 2nd and 3rd segment rates
less 100 basis points for Contributions.
After examining historical variability in this rate, we believe that
the selected assumptions do not significantly conflict with what
would be reasonable based on future expectations for this rate.
Annuity and lump sum Because the plan conversion basis makes use of IRC 417(e)(3)
conversion rate rates, which are based on high quality corporate bond rates, the
conversion basis is set equal to the assumed discount rate as of
the applicable measurement date. We believe that the selected
assumptions do not significanly conflict with what would be
reasonable based on current and historical values for these rates.
Rates of increase in Assumed increases were chosen as an estimate of future
compensation, National experience and are based on observed experience with input
Average Wages (NAW), CPI,
from the plan sponsor as appropriate. We believe the
and plan administrative
assumptions selected do not significantly conflict with what would

EIN / PN: 52-1568099/020
Plan Sponsor: Citigroup Inc.
Valuation Date: January 1, 2024

SCHEDULE SB ATTACHMENTS
Assumptions Rationale - Significant Demographic Assumptions
Healthy Mortality – Assumptions used for funding purposes are as prescribed by IRC
Contributions §430(h).
Termination Termination rates were based on an experience study conducted in
2021-2022, with annual consideration of whether any conditions have
changed that would be expected to produce different results in the future.
Assumed termination rates differ by age and service because of
observed differences in termination rates by age and service. For the
reasons discussed above, we believe the assumptions selected do not
significantly conflict with what would be reasonable.
Disability Disability rates were established based on a prior experience study, with
annual consideration of whether any conditions have changed that would
be expected to produce different results in the future. We believe the
assumptions selected do not significantly conflict with what would be
reasonable.
Retirement Retirement rates were based on an experience study conducted in 2021-
2022, with annual consideration of whether any conditions have changed
that would be expected to produce different results in the future. We
believe the assumptions selected do not significantly conflict with what
would be reasonable.
Benefit commencement
date for deferred benefits:
• Preretirement death Surviving spouses are assumed to begin benefits at the earliest
benefit permitted commencement date because ERISA requires benefits to start
then unless the spouse elects to defer. We believe the assumptions
selected do not significantly conflict with what would be reasonable.
• Deferred vested Deferred vested participants are assumed to begin benefits at normal
benefit retirement date based on an analysis of actual commencement patterns.
We believe the assumptions selected do not significantly conflict with
what would be reasonable.

SCHEDULE SB ATTACHMENTS
Form of payment The percentage of non-grandfathered retiring participants assumed to
take lump sums is based on observed experience.
For grandfathered participants, the assumption of a single life annuity is
utilized because none of the alternative forms of payment reflect an
additional subsidy. We believe the assumptions selected do not
significantly conflict with what would be reasonable.
Marital Assumptions
• Percent married The assumed percentage married is based on historical data for the
legacy populations. For the reasons discussed above, we believe the
assumptions selected do not significantly conflict with what would be
reasonable.
• Spouse age The assumed age difference for spouses is based on general population
statistics on the age difference for married individuals of retirement age.
For the reasons discussed above, we believe the assumptions selected
do not significantly conflict with what would be reasonable.
Prescribed Methods
Funding methods The methods used for funding purposes as described in this Appendix,
including the method of determining plan assets, are “prescribed
methods set by law”, as defined in the actuarial standards of practice
(ASOPs). These methods are required by IRC §430, or were selected by
the plan sponsor from a range of methods permitted by IRC §430.

filings or meet other requirements).

Actuarial Methods – Contributions
Measurement date First day of plan year
Funding target Present value of accrued benefits
The IRC 430 regulations describe the required methodology for
attributing benefits among Funding Target, current year Target
Normal Cost, and future years’ Target Normal Costs for disability
benefits, Social Security benefits, death benefits and other ancillary
benefits.
Target Normal Cost Present value of benefits expected to accrue during plan year plus
plan-related expenses expected to be paid from plan assets during
plan year
Actuarial value of assets Average of the fair market value of assets on the valuation date
and the two immediately preceding valuation dates, adjusted for
contributions, benefits, administrative expenses and expected
earnings (with such expected earnings limited as described in IRS
Notice 2009-22). The average asset value must be within 10% of
market value, including discounted contributions receivable
(discounted using the effective interest rate for the 2023 plan year.)
Benefits not valued All benefits described in the Plan Provisions section of this report
were valued. WTW has reviewed the plan provisions with Citigroup
and, based on that review, is not aware of any other significant
benefits required to be valued that were not.
Sources of Data and Other Information
Citigroup through its third-party administrators, furnished participant data and claims data as of
1/1/2024. Information on assets, contributions and plan provisions was supplied by the plan sponsor.
Data were reviewed for reasonableness and consistency, but no audit was performed. Based on
discussions with the plan sponsor, assumptions or estimates were made when data were not available,
and the data was adjusted to reflect any significant events that occurred between the date the data was
collected and the measurement date. In consultation with and approved by Citigroup, the 2024 data
action plans document the assumptions made for any missing data.
We are not aware of any errors or omissions in the data that would have a significant effect on the
results of our calculations.

SCHEDULE SB ATTACHMENTS
Assumptions Rationale - Significant Economic Assumptions
Discount rate – Contributions The basis chosen was selected by the plan sponsor from among
choices prescribed by law, all of which are based on observed
market data over certain periods of time.
Expected return on plan We understand that the expected return on assets assumption
assets reflects the plan sponsor’s estimate of future experience for trust
asset returns, reflecting the plan‘s current asset allocation and
any expected changes during the current plan year, current
market conditions and the plan sponsor’s expectations for future
market conditions. The analysis was informed by analysis of
historical data, benchmarking data, economists’ forecasts and
recent trends for CPI, GDP growth, and real returns on the
various classes of assets held by the trust. Willis Towers
Watson’s determination that this assumption does not significantly
conflict with what would be reasonable is informed by Willis
Towers Watson’s Expected Return Estimator model and historical
active management premiums experienced by the trust.
Cash balance interest The plan credits interest to cash balance accounts using the 30-
crediting rate year Treasury rate. The plan sponsor has selected an expected
future 30-year Treasury rate of 1% less than the discount rate for
Pension Cost and the average of the 2nd and 3rd segment rates
less 100 basis points for Contributions.
After examining historical variability in this rate, we believe that
the selected assumptions do not significantly conflict with what
would be reasonable based on future expectations for this rate.
Annuity and lump sum Because the plan conversion basis makes use of IRC 417(e)(3)
conversion rate rates, which are based on high quality corporate bond rates, the
conversion basis is set equal to the assumed discount rate as of
the applicable measurement date. We believe that the selected
assumptions do not significanly conflict with what would be
reasonable based on current and historical values for these rates.
Rates of increase in Assumed increases were chosen as an estimate of future
compensation, National experience and are based on observed experience with input
Average Wages (NAW), CPI,
from the plan sponsor as appropriate. We believe the
and plan administrative
assumptions selected do not significantly conflict with what would
expenses
be reasonable.
Plan Name: Citigroup Pension Plan
EIN / PN: 52-1568099/020
Plan Sponsor: Citigroup Inc.
Valuation Date: January 1, 2024

SCHEDULE SB ATTACHMENTS
Assumptions Rationale - Significant Demographic Assumptions
Healthy Mortality – Assumptions used for funding purposes are as prescribed by IRC
Contributions §430(h).
Termination Termination rates were based on an experience study conducted in
2021-2022, with annual consideration of whether any conditions have
changed that would be expected to produce different results in the future.
Assumed termination rates differ by age and service because of
observed differences in termination rates by age and service. For the
reasons discussed above, we believe the assumptions selected do not
significantly conflict with what would be reasonable.
Disability Disability rates were established based on a prior experience study, with
annual consideration of whether any conditions have changed that would
be expected to produce different results in the future. We believe the
assumptions selected do not significantly conflict with what would be
reasonable.
Retirement Retirement rates were based on an experience study conducted in 2021-
2022, with annual consideration of whether any conditions have changed
that would be expected to produce different results in the future. We
believe the assumptions selected do not significantly conflict with what
would be reasonable.
Benefit commencement
date for deferred benefits:
• Preretirement death Surviving spouses are assumed to begin benefits at the earliest
benefit permitted commencement date because ERISA requires benefits to start
then unless the spouse elects to defer. We believe the assumptions
selected do not significantly conflict with what would be reasonable.
• Deferred vested Deferred vested participants are assumed to begin benefits at normal
benefit retirement date based on an analysis of actual commencement patterns.
We believe the assumptions selected do not significantly conflict with
what would be reasonable.
Plan Name: Citigroup Pension Plan
EIN / PN: 52-1568099/020
Plan Sponsor: Citigroup Inc.
Valuation Date: January 1, 2024

SCHEDULE SB ATTACHMENTS
Form of payment The percentage of non-grandfathered retiring participants assumed to
take lump sums is based on observed experience.
For grandfathered participants, the assumption of a single life annuity is
utilized because none of the alternative forms of payment reflect an
additional subsidy. We believe the assumptions selected do not
significantly conflict with what would be reasonable.
Marital Assumptions
• Percent married The assumed percentage married is based on historical data for the
legacy populations. For the reasons discussed above, we believe the
assumptions selected do not significantly conflict with what would be
reasonable.
• Spouse age The assumed age difference for spouses is based on general population
statistics on the age difference for married individuals of retirement age.
For the reasons discussed above, we believe the assumptions selected
do not significantly conflict with what would be reasonable.
Prescribed Methods
Funding methods The methods used for funding purposes as described in this Appendix,
including the method of determining plan assets, are “prescribed
methods set by law”, as defined in the actuarial standards of practice
(ASOPs). These methods are required by IRC §430, or were selected by
the plan sponsor from a range of methods permitted by IRC §430.

Plan Name: Citigroup Pension Plan
EIN / PN: 52-1568099/020
Plan Sponsor: Citigroup Inc.
Valuation Date: January 1, 2024

SCHEDULE SB ATTACHMENTS
Schedule SB, Part V
Summary of Plan Provisions
Effective December 31, 2012, Citibank grandfathered participants whose pensionable earnings exceed
$250,000 in any plan year, will have their accrued benefits frozen under the Citigroup Pension Plan as of
the end of that year and all future benefits will be earned under the Citibank Pay Cap Plan, a non-qualified
plan.
Effective July 1, 2015, a full lump sum option is available to Citibank grandfathered participants (Section C)
and AFCC participants (Section G) for amounts under $200,000 if the participant does not have a
nonqualified benefit payable from Citi. This new option is available to both current and future terminated
participants.
On September 28, 2016, Citigroup completed a buy-out of its participating GR-1 contract with MetLife. The
transaction was reflected during the third quarterly remeasurement for 2016.
On September 13, 2017, Citigroup completed a buyout of approximately 15,000 retirees with MetLife. As a
result of the transaction, $257MM of PBO was released from the plan along with $269MM in corresponding
assets. The transaction was reflected by Citigroup during Q3.
Effective November 1, 2017, Citigroup expanded the eligibility for a lump sum form of payment to include
Shearson benefits (up to $200,000) and P3 cash balance account benefits (up to $200,000). No material
change in liability is anticipated for these changes although as of year-end, the payment assumption for P3
balances was changed to 100% lump sum, consistent with other P-type cash balance account benefits.
Effective November 1, 2018, all Citigroup benefits are eligible to be received as a lump sum with exception
for certain participants with nonqualified pension benefits.
Effective December 31, 2018 and each year-end thereafter, pension plan benefits were frozen for
grandfathered participants earning pay in excess of $120,000 in the year to ensure ongoing compliance
with IRC 401(a)(26) as plan size decreases.
Effective January 1, 2019, Citi harmonized optional forms of payment among all benefit groups by adding a
75% and 100% contingent annuitant form of payment to groups that did not previously have this option. A
50%, 75% and 100% contingent annuitant option was added for all groups that were part of lump sum
expansion but did not previously allow for pre-retirement commencements. Additionally, the ability to add a
non-spouse beneficiary for post-retirement survivor benefits was added.
On December 19, 2022 Citigroup completed a complete buy-out for participants who had previously had an
annuity purchased from Prudential Insurance Company for benefits accrued through December 31, 1986.
The transaction was reflected as of December 31, 2022.
With the exception of the above and increases in IRS pay and benefit limits for 2024, we are not aware of
any plan amendments impacting the January 1, 2024 valuations.
Note: For terminations after 2007, 3 years of vesting service is required to receive a vested benefit under
all plan formulas (5 years of vesting service is required for terminations before 2008).
In addition, immediate vesting was granted for all non-vested participants affected by the Salomon Smith
Barney joint venture, effective May 31, 2009.

The interest rate for interest credits during a calendar year is
determined as the average yield of 30-year U.S. Treasury Bonds for
the previous August, rounded to the nearest 0.1%.
The cash balance account accrued under this section is referred to as
the “P3 balance.”
For employees who were former TIC plan participants, the prior plan
accrued benefit was multiplied by 10 to convert to an opening balance
as of March 31, 1993. Additional pay credits were earned under a
different cash balance matrix for the period April 1, 1993 through
February 1, 1996 (12/31/1998 for transitional employees). This
portion of the cash balance account is referred to as the “CB1
balance.”
For employees who were former TIC plan participants and who were
hired between February 1, 1994 through January 31, 1996, the pay
credits were earned under the above cash balance matrix through
January 31, 1996. This portion of the cash balance account is
referred to as the “CB2 balance.”
The interest rate for Interest Credits during a calendar year for CB1
and CB2 balances is 6.0%. The CB1 and CB2 balances are not
payable as lump sums. The CB1 and CB2 balances are divided by 10
to convert to an annuity.
Employees who have accumulated either a CB1 balance or a CB2
balance begin receiving accruals under P3 as of February 1, 1996.
Grandfathered benefit Certain grandfathered participants receive the greater of the cash
balance benefit and benefits determined under the prior plan as
follows:
For employees who were former TIC plan participants on or before
December 31, 1989 and were at least age 45 on March 31, 1993, the
greater of the cash balance benefit and, the greater of Alternative 1 or
Alternative 2 (described below).
For employees who were former TIC plan participants after December
31, 1989 but before March 31, 1993, and were at least age 45 on
March 31, 1993, the greater of the cash balance benefit and
Alternative 1 (described below).

SCHEDULE SB ATTACHMENTS
Schedule SB, Part V
Summary of Plan Provisions
Effective December 31, 2012, Citibank grandfathered participants whose pensionable earnings exceed
$250,000 in any plan year, will have their accrued benefits frozen under the Citigroup Pension Plan as of
the end of that year and all future benefits will be earned under the Citibank Pay Cap Plan, a non-qualified
plan.
Effective July 1, 2015, a full lump sum option is available to Citibank grandfathered participants (Section C)
and AFCC participants (Section G) for amounts under $200,000 if the participant does not have a
nonqualified benefit payable from Citi. This new option is available to both current and future terminated
participants.
On September 28, 2016, Citigroup completed a buy-out of its participating GR-1 contract with MetLife. The
transaction was reflected during the third quarterly remeasurement for 2016.
On September 13, 2017, Citigroup completed a buyout of approximately 15,000 retirees with MetLife. As a
result of the transaction, $257MM of PBO was released from the plan along with $269MM in corresponding
assets. The transaction was reflected by Citigroup during Q3.
Effective November 1, 2017, Citigroup expanded the eligibility for a lump sum form of payment to include
Shearson benefits (up to $200,000) and P3 cash balance account benefits (up to $200,000). No material
change in liability is anticipated for these changes although as of year-end, the payment assumption for P3
balances was changed to 100% lump sum, consistent with other P-type cash balance account benefits.
Effective November 1, 2018, all Citigroup benefits are eligible to be received as a lump sum with exception
for certain participants with nonqualified pension benefits.
Effective December 31, 2018 and each year-end thereafter, pension plan benefits were frozen for
grandfathered participants earning pay in excess of $120,000 in the year to ensure ongoing compliance
with IRC 401(a)(26) as plan size decreases.
Effective January 1, 2019, Citi harmonized optional forms of payment among all benefit groups by adding a
75% and 100% contingent annuitant form of payment to groups that did not previously have this option. A
50%, 75% and 100% contingent annuitant option was added for all groups that were part of lump sum
expansion but did not previously allow for pre-retirement commencements. Additionally, the ability to add a
non-spouse beneficiary for post-retirement survivor benefits was added.
On December 19, 2022 Citigroup completed a complete buy-out for participants who had previously had an
annuity purchased from Prudential Insurance Company for benefits accrued through December 31, 1986.
The transaction was reflected as of December 31, 2022.
With the exception of the above and increases in IRS pay and benefit limits for 2024, we are not aware of
any plan amendments impacting the January 1, 2024 valuations.
Note: For terminations after 2007, 3 years of vesting service is required to receive a vested benefit under
all plan formulas (5 years of vesting service is required for terminations before 2008).
In addition, immediate vesting was granted for all non-vested participants affected by the Salomon Smith
Barney joint venture, effective May 31, 2009.

Preretirement survivor benefit Termination of employment due to death. Benefits are fully vested
upon death.
Benefits paid upon the following events
Normal or late retirement Accrued benefit determined as of retirement date.
Early retirement Accrued benefit determined as of early retirement date.
Deferred vested termination Accrued benefit determined as of the date of termination.
Disability Accrued benefit determined as of the date of disablement. For
employees on Long-Term Disability (LTD), pay credits are continued
for 29 months and 100% vesting granted after 29 months on LTD.
Death with preretirement Accrued Benefit determined as of the date of death. 100% of cash
survivor benefit balance account payable upon death.
Other
Forms of payment The normal form of payment is a single life annuity for single
participants and a 50% contingent annuity with the spouse as the
designated beneficiary for married participants.
Optional forms include a 1%, 50%, 75%, or 100% contingent annuity, a
cash refund annuity, a level income option, and a single life annuity (for
married participants). The normal form of payment is converted to an
optional form using the applicable interest rates and mortality table as
defined in Code Section 417(e).
Participants can elect to receive benefits in the form of a lump sum
distribution.
Maximum on benefits All benefits and pay for any calendar year may not exceed the
and pay maximum limitations for that year as defined by the Internal Revenue
Code. The plan provides for increasing the dollar limits automatically
as such changes become effective.

participants), and a lump sum. The normal form of payment is

mortality table as defined in code section 417(e).

code. The plan provides for increasing the dollar limits automatically

Plan provisions for grandfathered legacy Associates First Capital Corporation employees
(section G)
Effective date Amended and restated effective January 1, 1999. Effective December
31, 2018 and each year-end thereafter, pension plan benefits are frozen
for participants earning pay in excess of $120,000 in the year to ensure
ongoing compliance with IRC 401(a)(26) as plan size decreases.
Covered employees Associates First Capital Corporation employees age 53 or older with at
least 8 years of service as of December 31, 2001, age 63 or older with
at least 3 years of service as of December 31, 2001, or age 50 or older
with at least 10 years of service and where age plus service equals at
least 65 as of December 31, 2001.
Participation date November 1, 1989 for employees who were participants in a
predecessor Plan. First of the month following the attainment of twenty
one years of age and the completion of one year of eligibility service for
employees hired after November 1, 1989.
Definitions
Eligibility service For full-time employees, 12-month period during which 365 days are
credited. For part-time employees, 12-month period during which at
least 1,000 hours are credited.
Vesting service 12-month period during which 365 days are credited.
Benefit service For full-time employees, 12-month period during which 365 days are
credited. For part-time employees, 12-month period during which at
least 1,000 hours are credited and the employee works a complete
calendar year.
Compensation Base pay prior to pre-tax contributions, including overtime, commissions
and cash bonuses.
Final average compensation Compensation averaged over the highest paid 5 consecutive years in
the last 10 years of employment.
Social Security Annual primary insurance amount payable at age 65 under the Social
Security Act, in effect on the earlier of his normal retirement date or the
date his employment ceases.
Normal retirement date First of month coincident with or next following the attainment of age 65.
Accrued benefit
2% of Final Average Compensation (FAC) times benefit service up to
20 years; plus 1% of final average compensation times benefit service
over 20 years; minus 1.25% of Social Security benefit times benefit
service (for participants hired prior to 1976, limited to 40 years*); minus
retirement benefits derived from account balance of the Profit Sharing
Plan as of December 31, 1967, if any. In no event shall the offset
exceed 1% of FAC times benefit service.
*For these participants, a 1% of FAC times benefit service formula also applies.
